curiosity_phrases: Gumbo is usually called a Cajun dish, but there are both Cajun and Creole varieties.
Gumbo is a complex and delicious stew or thick soup that originated in southern Louisiana.
Stuffed shells are made with conchiglioni pasta, the larger version of conchiglie, which means "conch shells".
The sloppy joe goes by many names, including manwich, slush burger, yum yums,barbecue, dynamite, and even sloppy jane.
Most believe the sloppy joe was first served in Havannah Cuba at the bar and café "Sloppy Joe's" in the early 1900's.
Hash browns were originally called hashed brown potatoes first mentioned by food author Maria Parloa in 1888.
The hashed brown potatoes gained popularity in New York City hotels during the 1890s.
A BLT is a type of sandwich, named for the initials of its primary ingredients, bacon, lettuce and tomato.
The BLT is still the second-most popular sandwich in the United States, as the simple ham sandwich is first.
Pesto has a French relative, pistou, a sauce typical from Marseille.
There's a World Pesto Championship, organized by the Cultural Association of Italian Gourmets and it takes place every two years in Genova.
Mint gets its name from Menthe a Greek mythical character.
Ancient Romans and Greeks used mint to flavor cordials and fruit compotes also for baths and perfumes.
Mint has been found in Egyptian tombs from as far back as 1000 BC.
Red bell peppers are sweeter than green ones because bell peppers sweeten as they ripen.
Red bell peppers have more than twice the vitamin C of a green pepper.
Red bell peppers are simply green bell peppers that have been left on the vine to continue to ripen.
Garlic is among the oldest known horticultural crops.
China produces the most garlic.
Garlic's health benefits are myriad, including an ability to reduce cholesterol.
Basil is native to tropical Asia and belongs to the mint family.
Licorice Basil is an Asian decorative plant.
Basil was found in mummies in Egypt because the ancient Egyptians used this herb for embalming.
Italians once believed that eggplants made you insane.
Eggplants were once used to dye teeth for fashion.
Eggplants are reported to have the highest level of nicotine of any other vegetable.
The word tortilla comes from the Spanish word torta which means round cake.
According to a Mayan legend, tortilla was invented by a peasant for his hungry king in ancient times.
In 2000, the overall tortilla market in the United States was an estimated 4 billion dollars.
The actual beginning of cheese rolling or cheese rolls is unknown, however, it is thought to have begun in the 1800s.
Cod fish are slow swimmers.
Humans are the only natural enemies or predators of the cod fish.
Soy ink is used to print newspapers and textbooks.
The soy bean is called the "Miracle Bean" because of its amazing versatility.
Soy beans were discovered in China over 5,000 years ago.
During medieval times, the green pigment extracted from spinach was used as ink for artwork.
Kaju means cashew nut in Hindi.
Butternut squash is loaded with Vitamin A.
The name squash comes from the Narragansett Indian term “askutasquash”, which means raw or uncooked.
Mardi gras salad is a festive salad that tries to mirror the vibrant green, purple and gold of the King Cake.
Yangzhou fried rice is the most popular fried rice served in Chinese restaurants, commonly referred to simply as "special fried rice" or "house fried rice".
The egg roll has various features of the Cantonese cuisine and therefore, Southern China is mostly credited as being its sole inventor.
Quinoa is pronounced Keen-wah.
Quinoa thrives in diverse conditions when other crops would fail including low rainfall, high altitudes, hot sun, freezing temperatures and poor soil conditions.
Quinoa is naturally gluten free so is suitable for people who are coeliac or gluten intolerant.
The main ingredient in most dry pet food is corn.
One bushel of corn will sweeten more than 400 cans of Coca-Cola.
Crepes get their name from the Latin word Crispus, meaning undulated and crinkly.
In Italy, many people prefer to have crepes baked in an oven as an alternative to lasagna.
There are more than 15000 species of clams, but only 150 are edible.
Clams catch plankton for food in a process that purifies the water by filtering pollutants and pathogens.
If we literally translate mapo tofo, we get pockmarked grandma’s tofu.
Mapo tofo is often thought to be related with an old lady with pockmarks who lived in Chengdu during the Qing Dynasty in the 1860s.
The ancient Roman cookbook Apicius included many meatball type recipes.
Baguettes became extremely popular in france in the 1700s and it is often considered the national bread of france.
baguette means in english either stick, wand or baton.
Kale is high in fiber, antioxidants, vitamin A and calcium.
kale is fat and sodium free.
The oldest known recipe using Fritos brand corn chips with chili was published in Texas in 1949.
It is believed that Frito pie was created somewhere in Mexico and was popular at fiestas before it took off in other countries like the United States.
Jalapenos have been in space, they have been taken on board the Columbia space shuttle in the 1980s.
Jalapenos grow best in slightly acidic soil with a pH between 6 and 7.
Dumplings are not made to be cut, as most of them are specially made in a perfect size to fit in your mouth in one bite.
Dumplings can be Cooked 3 Different Ways: they can be steamed, pan fried, or boiled.
Brisket is a cut of meat from the breast or lower chest of beef or veal.
In Mexican cuisine, brisket is known as suadero and it's commonly slowly cooked in a circular pan in taco stands all over the country.
When cooking on a gas stove, using too high heat can harm your pan.
Apple peels can be used to bring the shine back to aluminum pots and pans, by boiling the peels on them.
A saucepan is great for cooking anything like mashed potatoes, risotto, lentils, or any other grain that requires boiling.
Crabs are decapods, meaning they have 10 legs.
Female crabs can release 1000 to 2000 eggs at once.
It’s thought that tomatoes originally came from Peru.
La Tomatina is an annual festival in Spain, where people throw around 150,000 tomatoes at each other.
Rose syrup can be made by adding sugar to rose water.
There are less than 1000 onion farmers in the United States.
The first meal eaten on the moon included bacon.
Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin ate bacon squares, peaches, coffee, among other stuff after their moon landing in 1969.
Back in the day, most carrots were purple.
In the late 1970s, Onion Nuggets were tested in a few McDonald's markets but never had great success.
Graham crackers were created in the 1800s as a way to prevent sexual urges.
Pound cake got its name because the original 1795 recipe contained 1 pound of each main ingredient.
On British Evacuation Day in 1783, George Washington feasted on a carrot cake.
Brussels sprouts, kale, broccoli, cabbage, cauliflower, and kohlrabi all come from the same plant.
Pasta is not Italian. Marco Polo brought it to Venice from China.
The oldest type of pasta (noodle) is four thousand years old and used to be made out of millet.
Pasta was a common side dish during the Middle Ages and Renaissance, even in Italy. However, it wasn't until recently that it became a staple of Italian cuisine.
Pasta became a popular main dish in Naples in the 17th Century.
Pizza Margherita was a 19th Century invention and was named after Italy’s queen in 1889.
Pizza Margherita was initially created to feature Italy’s colours and was prepared for Queen Margherita in 1889.
The Spanish were the first to use tomatoes to make sauces. They were then followed by the Italians. Tomato sauce was often used to accompany meat or fish dishes.
A single cargo ship in the 2nd Century, bringing black pepper from India to Europe would pay the annual salary of around 7000 soldiers. That’s how expensive pepper was!
Salt used to be a trading currency back in the day. Salary, in latin, derives from the word salt.
When tomatoes were brought to Europe (during the Columbian Exchange), their only use was decorative.
Chilli peppers come from Mesoamerica and were brought to Europe during the Columbian Exchange.
Before the 17th Century, spices were scarce, expensive, and only belonged to the ruling classes.
Ancient Greeks used oyster shells to cast some votes. In trials, the jury would write the verdict onto the shell of an oyster.
Ancient Greeks used oyster shells at trials, which gave origin to the word 'ostracise' ('ostreon' is the ancient Greek word for 'oyster').
In 1516, Bavaria instated 'Reinheitsgebot', a purity law that allowed beer to be made using only water, barley and hops.
In 1516, Bavaria regulated a beer manifacturing law to avoid poisonous ingredients, which was one of the very first food safety laws in history.
During the 19th Century, the English set harsh and restrictive controls over the Irish food supply, leaving the Irish to eat almost exclusively potatoes.
China is the world’s largest carrot producer.
Fried chicken became popular in Southern US after the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863.
The first hot chicken establishment opened in a black neighbourhood in Nashville in 1945.
Prison food is the term for meals served to prisoners.
Seasonal food refers to the times of the year when the harvest or the flavor of a given type of food is at its peak.
Shelf-stable food is a type of food that can be safely stored at room temperature in a sealed container.
Space food is a type of food product created and processed for consumption by astronauts in outer space.
Traditional foods are foods and dishes that are passed through generations.
Humans have five different types of tastes: sweet, sour, salty, bitter, and umami.
Many scholars claim that the rhetorical function of food is to represent the culture of a country, and that it can be used as a form of communication.
About 2% of adults and 8% of children have a food allergy.
Common food allergens are gluten, corn, shellfish, peanuts, and soy.
The Chinese beer market is the largest in the world.
The oldest beer recipe in the world dates back to 1800 before christ in Mesopotamia.
Curry houses started to bloom in the UK when in 1948 Britain passed a law allowing all Commonwealth citizens to work in the UK.
In Australia, there are fruit salad trees, which can grow up to six different type of fruits.
Cookie Monster's cookies are actually painted rice cakes, in the show.
Pineaples can take two to three years to grow.
Peppers have more vitamin C than oranges and the amount depends on its color.
Limes are denser than lemons, therefore limes sink on water, whereas lemons don't.
A single spaghetti noodle is called a spaghetto.
Broccoli contains more protein than steak.
Apples provide more energy than coffee.
Avocados and Pistachios are fruits.
Americans eat approximately 20 million hot dogs a year, just on baseball games.
Cucumbers can help with fogging windows, by rubbing them against the glass. It also provides a spa-like fragrance.
Bananas can float in water.
Humans share about 50% or more of their DNA with bananas.
One fast food burger can have meat from 100 different cows.
Fruit flavored snacks shine because of car wax.
Crackers have holes in them to not suffer shape metamorphosis during baking.
In the 19th century ketchup used to be used as a medicine.
Crackers are worse for the teeth's health than sugar.
There's a chemical in chili peppers called capsaicin that tricks your mouth into feeling like it's being burned
American cheese is not actually American.
Cheese is the most stolen food in the world.
One in four hazelnuts ends up in Nutella.
A corned beef sandwich has once been smuggled into space by an astronaut.
Chocolate has once been used as a currency in ancient civilizations, such as Mexico and South America.
McDonald's sells about 2.5 billion hamburgers every year.
Expiration dates on bottled water have nothing to do with the water, but rather to the bottles themselves.
Honey can be considered as bee vomit.
Himalayan salt, also known as pink salt, is a rock salt mined from the Punjab region of Pakistan.
Pesto is a sauce from Genoa, Italy.
In Britain, eggnog was originally popular among the aristocracy since milk, eggs, and sherry were foods of the wealthy.
The first chocolate drink is believed to have been created by the Maya around 2500 to 3000 years ago.
Tom and Jerry drink was a favorite of President Warren G. Harding, who served it at an annual Christmas party for his closest friends.
An early recipe of mashed potatos can be found found in Hannah Glasse's The Art of Cookery, in 1747.
The earliest examples of Christmas cookies in the United States were brought by the Dutch in the early 17th century.
The Thanksgiving holiday's history in North America is rooted in English traditions dating from the Protestant Reformation.
Coffee beans can help eliminate bad breath.
Potatoes are about 80% of water.
According to a 2014's study, 49% of Americans over 20 eat a sandwich every day.
Turkey is the country with the most amount of tea consumption per person.
The Netherlands drinks the most coffee per person.
In Colombia, dried ants is the popular snack option when going to the movies.
In Korea, dried cuttlefish is the popular snack option when going to the movies.
In China, dried salted plums is the popular snack option when going to the movies.
Tonic water glows in the dark.
India has the lowest meat consumption in the world.
Nutritious food is generally more expensive than junk food.
Fortune cookies are actually not Chinese, but rather American.
You could survive only by drinking breast milk.
The amount of Nutella sold every year, could cover the world 1.8 times.
Goat meat accounts for 70% of the red meat eaten globally, making it the more popular meat.
Throwing food away is illegal in Seattle.
Astronauts ate food grown in space for the first time in 2015.
In the united states of america 40% of food produce grown is never sold just because it’s too ugly.
Australians eat the most meat.
Americans eat around 500 million pounds of peanut butter each year.
There are more Indian restaurants in London than in Mumbai or Delhi.
The original Margherita pizza was color-coded.
Not eating before bed burns fat.
The Domino's co-founder traded his shares for a Volkswagen, while the other many years after for one billion dollars.
Water requirements for growing avocados are three times higher than for apples, and 18 times higher than for tomatoes.
Production and consumption of rice is estimated to have been responsible for 4% of global greenhouse gas emissions in 2010.
Oryza sativa, rice was first domesticated in the Yangtze River basin in China 13500 to 8200 years ago.
China and India are the two main producers of rice summing up to around 400 million tonnes of rice produced.
Sushi as it is known these days is only 200 years old.
Futomaki is a more popular variation of sushi within the United States.
Sustainable sushi is made from fished or farmed sources that can be maintained or whose future production does not significantly jeopardize the ecosystems from which it is acquired.
Sushi is sometimes confused with sashimi, a related dish in Japanese cuisine that consists of thinly sliced raw fish or occasionally meat.
China is the largest consumer of rice.
With the worldwide demand for pasta, it is now largely mass-produced in factories and only a tiny proportion is crafted by hand.
The two largest producers of dried pasta are the United States and Italy.
In the 1497, the expedition to India by the portuguese, Vasco da Gama, revealed the curative effects of citrus fruit.
Fruit allergies make up about 10 percent of all food related allergies.
Osage orange fruits are used to repel cockroaches.
Pumpkins are carved into Jack-o lanterns for Halloween.
Fruit is often a subject of still life paintings.
Bayberry fruits provide a wax often used to make candles.
Many dry fruits are used as decorations or in dried flower arrangements.
Many fruits provide natural dyes.
The coconut palm is one of the most useful trees in the world.
According to an urban legend, more deaths are caused by falling coconuts than by sharks annually.
The edible white, fleshy part of the coconut seed is known as the coconut meat.
Indonesia is the world's largest producer of coconuts, with gross production of around 15 million tonnes.
Coconut palms are normally cultivated in hot and wet tropical climates.
Vitamin C was discovered in 1912
Vitamin C was the first vitamin to be synthesized.
Milking machines were invented in 1984.
Other than cows, water buffalo, camels, goats, sheep, horses and even reindeer are milked.
All 'cows' are female? Only males are called bulls.
A cow has 32 teeth.
A cow will spend about 8 hours a day eating.
Cows can see in color and can smell up to six miles away.
The word 'meat' comes from the Old English word 'mete', which referred to food in general.
Meat is mainly composed of water, protein, and fat.
The term hamburger originally derives from Hamburg, Germany‘s second-largest city.
American Lobsters have longer life spans than both cats and dogs, living over 20 years.
Catfish have over 27,000 taste buds, whereas humans have only 9,000.
Croaker is the loudest fish that can be found.
Fish typically have quite small brains relative to body size, around 0.06 percent.
Fish can get sunburn, however being unusual.
Antarctic ice fish, which have antifreeze in their blood, live permanently at -1 degrees Celcius.
Fish have a specialised sense organ, which works as a radar, helping them navigate in the dark.
Only after 1853 in London with a deep understanding of aeration and filtration of water, were people able to keep fishes as pets.
The word 'dessert' originated from the French word 'desservir', meaning 'to clear the table.'.
Coke defined the visual appearence of Santa we know these days.
The Netherlands brought to world the concept of leaving cookies and milk for Santa.
'Jingle Bells' was originally a Thanksgiving song.
During christmas season, ham and turkey usually reach the top of their popularity in the google search engine.
Candy Canes were once only white.
Candy Canes have a German origin root, which gain popularity in the US in the 19th century.
Salad comes from the Latin word 'herba salta' or 'salted herbs', because it was usually seasoned with lots of salt.
Christopher Columbus introduced lettuce to the Americas.
Lettuce is the second most popular fresh vegetable in the US behind potatoes.
China is the largest spinach producer in the world with 90% of global production.
Iceberg lettuce got its name from the way it was shipped with ice in old train carriages.
McDonald's salads are more rich in fat than their burgers.
For a short time in the 90s, Caesar salad was made illegal in California because it contained raw egg.
Humans are eating 900% more broccoli than they did 20 years ago.
Cucumbers have the highest water content of any vegetable.
Leonardo da Vinci was the first artist to depict salad in his paintings.
Mushrooms are more closely related to humans than to plants.
There is a wild mushroom that tastes nearly identical to chicken or fried chicken.
Magic Mushrooms are called 'magic' for their psychedelic properties.
In the Middle Ages people thought mushrooms grew at night on the soil where witches had had a sabbath.
The first pasta factory in the US was built in Brooklyn.
Butter color can depend on the cow's diet it was derived from.
India is the largest producer of butter.
Butter is a source of vitamin A, E, D, and K.
Not all oranges are orange. Some are green or yellow when ripe.
Japanese Yubari cantaloupes are the most expensive fruit in the world.
Two Yubari melons have once been sold at auction for 23500 dollars.
Donut peaches are a natural mutant peach variety, not a human-engineered fruit.
Grapefruit can cause dangerous reactions with some prescription medications.
Cranberries are a bouncy fruit.
Cranberries don't actually grow underwater, only at harvest time are cranberry bogs artificially flooded with water.
The leaves of the rhubarb plant are extremely poisonous.
One pomegranate can hold more than 1000 seeds
A strawberry isn't technically a berry, or even a fruit.
Apples float in water because they are 25% air.
Each pineapple plant only produces one pineapple per year.
Ancient herbarium list strawberries as a medicinal cure as early as the 13th century.
The cacao bean is native to mexico and both central and south america.
Marie antoinette loved hot chocolate.
Cacao beans was once used as currency by the Aztecs.
Napolean demanded that wine and chocolate were made available to him and his senior advisers even during intense military campaigns.
Milk chocolate was invented in switzerland.
It takes about 400 cacao beans to make a single pound of chocolate.
Ancient Greeks used ovens mainly to make bread.
An oven made specifically for use in metalwork is known as a furnace.
An oven made specifically to fire ceramics and other items is called a kiln.
−89.2 ºC or −128.6 °F is the coldest temperature ever recorded on Earth.
Absolute zero is the coldest theoretical temperature corresponding to -459.69 degrees Fahrenheit.
Only 51% of the proteins in raw eggs are digestible, while 91% of the proteins in cooked eggs are digestible.
Eggshell colors have nothing to do with the flavor or nutritional value of the egg.
To avoid teary eyes when cutting onions, cut them under cold running water, or briefly place them in the freezer before cutting.
Fresh lemon juice removes onion scent from hands.
Whipped cream, with or without flavorings, was known as 'snow cream' or 'milk snow' until the 17th century.
Fresh unpasteurised milk originates a fat layer, which when skimmed off is known as cream, often used in deserts.
The average American eats 35000 cookies in a lifetime.
'Blonde brownies' are a variation of brownies flavored with brown sugar, rather than chocolate.
Pizzelle is the name of traditional italian waffle cookies.
According to FDA regulation, peanut butter can only be called so, if it is made of at least 90% of peanuts.
Spices are highly rich in antioxidant.
Vitamin E is a powerful antioxidant often found in nuts, cereals and sweet potatoes.
Studies suggest that blueberries contain the highest amount of antioxidants among all commonly consumed fruits and vegetables.
At first store-bought salad dressings were sold in wooden jars.
A 2004 study showed that Russia is the only market in Europe where mayonnaise is sold more than ketchup by volume.

McDonald's fries were cooked in beef fat until 1990.
Rainbow corn is a thing.
Ketchup was once believed to have medicinal qualities that could cure, among other ailments, diarrhea.
Ears of corn generally have an even number of rows, which is usually 16.
Scientists can theoretically turn peanut butter into diamonds.
Farm-raised salmon is naturally white and then dyed pink.
Wild salmon are naturally pink due to the large amount of shrimp in their diet.
Potatoes can absorb and reflect Wi-fi signals.
Raw oysters might still be alive when they are eaten at restaurants.
oysters don't have central nervous systems, so they can't feel pain.
There are 1000 varieties of bananas all over the world, however the common banana is a genetic clone of the Cavendish variety.
In 1979, a chicken laid 371 eggs that year, beating all known records.
About 99% of all wasabi sold in the United States is fake.
Most wasabi seen in restaurants is actually just dyed horseradish.
Grapes will explode if you put them in the microwave.
Processed cheese was invented in Switzerland.
Oreo Cookies are not vegan-friendly.
Froot loops are all the same flavor, even though some have different colors.
Theoretically, wine can be used to fuel a car.
Rhubarb grow so fast (one inch per day), it is possible to hear it creak and pop.
There's a Black Market for Cheese.
Mushrooms are very hard to overcook due to their cell walls.
Chopsticks were initially created for cooking, not as an eating utensil.
Humans started cooking around 2 million years ago.
Pastries date back to Ancient Greece, Rome and Phoenicia.
TV shows about food inspire viewers to eat more but not to cook more.
The iconic chef's hat is called a toque.
The fear of cooking is called "mageirocophobia".
Microwaving is the healthiest way to cook vegetables.
Americans eat over a billion buffalo wings on Super Bowl weekend.
Pepperoni rolls originated as a meal for coal miners.
Chocolate fondue used to be made with Toblerone.
Nachos were named after a man called Nacho.
The word pretzel means "little reward".
Candy floss was invented by a dentist.
Popcorn was the first food to be microwaved.
In the United States, on the 18th of january, it's the national day of honey's lover, Winnie the Pooh.
California produces almost all of the broccoli sold in the United States.
A hornworm can eat an entire tomato plant by itself in one day.
Oats were one of the earliest cereals cultivated by man, being known in ancient China as long ago as 7000 before christ.
Oatmeal cookies are the number one non-cereal usage for oatmeal.
Mousse is pronounced "moose."
Whipped cream can be substituted for egg whites in a mousse recipe.
The first written record of chocolate mousse in the United States dates back to 1892.
April 3rd is the National Chocolate Mousse Day.
The annual world fish catch is about 75% salt water fish and 25% fresh water fish.
About 10% of the world fish catch is cod.
More than 90% of all fish caught are caught in the northern hemisphere.
The phrase "in a pickle" was first introduced by Shakespeare in one of his plays.
Cleopatra ate pickles since she believed they would help her stay beautiful.
The cinnamon tree can grow up to 60 feet.
Cinnamon sticks are also called quills.
The word "cookie" comes from the Dutch word koekje, meaning "small cake".
Peanut butter cookies are the second most popular type of cookies in the United States.
In the United States, on the 18th of august, it's the national fajita day.
Fajita creation dates back to the 30s of last century.
"Fajita" Translates to "Little Band", in Spanish.
Astronauts love beef jerky.
Each vegan spares 30 animal lives a year.
The term "vegan" was coined by the British animal rights activist Donald Watson in the 1940s.
Famous vegans include Benedict Cumberbatch, Joaquin Phoenix, Beyoncé, Bill Clinton, among others.
Vegans may replace meat with tofu, beans, lentils, wheat gluten, nuts, or seeds.
There are 3 types of vegetarians: Lacto-ovo vegetarians, Lacto vegetarians and Vegans.
The first Vegetarian Society was formed in England in 1847.
Currently about 70% of the world’s vegetarians are Indians.
